review_title: It's good to give back to the college who has given me so much
job_title: Student Ambassador in Grove City, PA
pros: I love being able to give back a little to an organization who gave me so much
cons: The pay is not great-- but it's worth it

job_title: Teacher Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: Plenty of hours provided and flexible schedule.
cons: The minimum hourly wage for all TA positions, no matter workload.

review_title: Writing Center Tutor at Grove City College
job_title: Writing Tutor in Grove City, PA
pros: flexible scheduling, enjoyable work with students
cons: Very low pay, not many hours available per week

review_title: Fun Side Hustle as a Student
job_title: Physical Learning Center Weight Room Attendant in Grove City, PA
pros: Very laid-back, easy to supervise, haven't encountered many difficult people or issues.
cons: Desk is by the door so it gets pretty chilly around the winter, pay is only $7 but then again all you do is sit there and I did homework most of the time.

job_title: Data Systems Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: Working here is liking coming home to your family. Everyone cares about each other and works together to get things done. We celebrate the highs of life together and walk through the lows of life together. You couldn't pick a better group of people to work with.
cons: There are reduced hours in the summer which can effect your pay if you are hourly instead of salary.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grove City, PA
pros: Work experience, great people, and flexible hours.
cons: Low pay and number low hours.

job_title: Media Services Technician in Grove City, PA
pros: great opportunity to work with quality audio/visual equipment, great coworkers who are eager to help, bosses are flexible and kind people
cons: the pay is minimum wage which does not reflect the complexity of setting up for bigger campus events

job_title: Student Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: Professional development opportunities are stellar
cons: The pay is just minimum wage

job_title: Graduate Student in State College, PA
pros:
Welcoming, engaging student body.
Excellent pay and benefits.
Flexible organization.
cons:
Unsupportive and dismissive administration
Noncollaborative work environment
Highly political environment

review_title: Great students, horrible department chair, limited culture
pros: The kids are amazing and do fantastic things. If they would focus less on just the grade, however, it could be something really spectacular. Great facilities to work in.
cons:
Department Chair has ulterior motives and in general, not a people-person at all. Not sure they could manage a fruit stand profitably, and certainly can't hold a conversation for more than a minute or so. 

The college is no longer focusing on the mission as much as the political statement they hope to make, which is a shame. While the value is still there, with an emphasis on political agendas, students are becoming turned off. Third and fourth generation Grovers will continue to send their kids there, but at this point, there really is not much room for folks with a different opinion on politics and/or government.

review_title: Open and deeply encouraging atmosphere, responsible administration
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: The entrepreneurship professor I was a teaching assistant for was very professional, understanding, and a really great pleasure to work with. He didn't hesitate to introduce me to other professors in the department, and he would go above and beyond to help my career path any way he could. His office was always open if I had questions or concerns about the work, and he was very flexible and easy to talk with.
cons: Pay scale seems a little odd since the students working in the dish rooms get paid the same minimum wage as those doing their homework during a desk shift. However, that's probably an irresolvable issue since they're both under minimum wage laws and honestly the college is as financially responsible as can be. Any deviation for how they fund their projects and programs now would probably be a downgrade.

job_title: Institutional Advancement Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: It provides a wonderful part-time job opportunity.  I was fortunate enough to work in the Alumni Office and get more administrative experience, as well as being able to work with caring and compassionate people.  It also provided a way to network with Grove City alum.
cons: Some of the tasks were menial, but that was to be expected.  It was a nice part-time experience and I was able to balance work with my education.  I also made a lot of solid connections with the staff and still keep in touch with them post-graduation.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: I worked as a TA for a professor for four years. It's a great way to make a little extra money, and depending on which professor you work for the time can be quite flexible. I was even able to log hours not worked directly in the office if I was doing work besides grading. Definitely better than sitting at a desk in the gym or a dorm logging hours.
cons: The pay is really not great. If you worked at the outlets you would probably make more, but then you would have to commute. I think it's minimum wage and then they take out state taxes.

review_title: Very nice place to have not just a job but a career
pros: Friendly staff/faculty. Many opportunities to learn and grow in your field and in other fields. Absolutely beautiful campus.  Technology is up to date and well supported. Benefit package is better than any other place I've worked. This is a place to stay and build a career.
cons: Some areas do not have a lot of room for advancement.  The college hires a lot of graduates/alumni. This is only a "con" if you are not an alum!

review_title: Great community of people, but small minded group think
pros:
*Most of the people that work here are great 
*Positive environment in my department
*Nice students who are hard working and respectful
*Our program was pretty well-funded
*Beautiful campus
*Positive Christian atmosphere
*Flexible schedule
*Summers off
cons:
*Everyone is overworked doing multiple jobs that should be full time by themselves
*Low pay- the school is breaking labor laws and illegally classifying some of the intern positions as paid internships with a stipend when the job duties don't meet the legal qualifications to be an "internship" with only stipend and exempt status
*The school likes to hire alumni or people from the conference the school competes in for sports which results in lots of employees who are not qualified for their jobs and who have only been at GCC or at similar schools in their network. This results in lots of incompetence and a very small world view and lacking of knowledge of ways to do things better since few people have worked at other more successful schools before coming here.
*Management did not have the backbone to stand up and advocate for our department's needs and also frequently lied and made false promises to employees
*If you are not a GCC alum or from an area school, you will not be favored here and will have little room for advancement even if your work is outstanding. Management wants "yes men" who they can easily control.
*At times people at this school can swing too far on the ultra conservative side which leads to discrimination against women, LGBTQ+ people, and minorities.
*Not very diverse campus.
*School is located in small town 45 min away from a large city- nothing to do in Grove City
*Intern pay is too low to afford the health insurance offered by the school.

job_title: Crimson Caller in Grove City, PA
pros: This job provided flexible hours, a fun working environment, a deeper appreciate for my school and alumni network, and developed my phone communication skills.
cons: During the slower giving periods, the job can be a bit tedious. During this periods, however, learning how to converse with an alumni who were not planning on giving to the school increased my confidence and made me a better employee.

review_title: Excellent academics and great preparation for employment or grad school.
pros: Great culture of friendliness as everybody tries to work hard to advance the values of the college. Students are willing to work hard to improve their skills.
cons: Grove City is a pretty small town, so there isn't a whole lot to do within the city limits. Also, the student body is more homogenous compared with most schools.

job_title: Student Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: Good brief work for students, friendly staff, good environment. Plenty of networking opportunities to attend. Buildings are beautiful and well cared for.
cons: Work can be boring and one dimensional. People frequently do not get back to you in a timely manner. Weather is certainly cold and not for the faint of heart, but it can be a beautiful part of the country to live in.

review_title: I am a student assistant that edits writing, prepares PowerPoints, and grades tests.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Grove City, PA
pros: Relatively flexible hours, jobs on campus can help build a good reputation on campus and provide job opportunities for the future.  The supervisors that I have interacted with have been kind and understanding of the demands on a student-worker.
cons: Almost all available jobs are minimum wage, very little room for advancement.  Some scheduling issues may arise from complex student and professor schedules.

job_title: Office Coordinator in Grove City, PA
pros: Flexible hours, kind bosses, autonomy.  A lot of training in the beginning, but after you learn everything there is a great amount of autonomy.  Meeting with your supervisor at the beginning of your shift, and then you are left to complete your tasks.
cons: Can be high pressure, non-responsive customers.  This is great for people who thrive on deadlines.  You might be asked to complete tasks in the evening.

pros: The other employees here are great to work with and it is a fun atmosphere to be a part of.
cons: The work can be a little tedious at times.

job_title: Federal Work Study Student in Tempe, AZ
pros: Lovely work environment, friendly co-workers and clients, flexible schedule, no opportunities for advancing career
cons: Maximum 20 hours a week

pros: Often feels like an extended family. Lots of support from staff. Medical benefits have been great. Don't seem to hold a grudge if you leave. Will often welcome you back if things don't work out.
cons: Salary's do not compare to industry and therefore great staff leave for more money. Often push for "emergency" information but then never hear about follow through. Not many opportunities for growth professionally or to increase pay. Professors don't earn vacation time. Are expected to respond to students within 24 hours therefore basically working 7 days a week. Schedule mandatory activities during breaks making it hard to take time off. President of University seems disconnected.

pros: Fantastic people and atmosphere. Fun, fast, friendly, and family are parts of UAT's values. Incredibly high ethical standards. Fantastic opportunities for students and employees to participate in community projects. The mission includes "to educate students" which most universities do not include. At UAT the student is the priority and our courses are tailored to make them the best they can be. This dedication to the student shows in our industry-leading alumni.
cons: You can't be uninvolved, slow, or rude. And you especially can't do anything that undermines a student or fellow worker.

review_title: An excellent place to work as an instructor
pros: UAT is a fantastic school that has a lot of really great students from a wide range of back grounds. I enjoy my coworkers and their perspectives and I certainly love the men and women I interact with on a daily basis in the class room.
cons: I don't really have any complaints. I have had the opportunity to work at many different educational institutions and I find UAT to be the best one I have worked at so far.

job_title: Resource and Content Coordinator in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great family environment that makes you feel at home. No one takes themselves too seriously, which makes it easier to approach anyone regardless of their role. Everyone wants to see everyone succeed. Benefits are great!  The option to continue your education while employed is another great benefit and can help you succeed even more with your job there.
cons: I cannot think of any at this time.

pros: I enjoy working here, it's simple, I can get my homework done if there's not much to do, most employees are nice that I come in contact with.
cons: There are occasional rude remarks here and there. Bit of nagging, but workplaces can't be perfect.

job_title: Office Assistant (Federal Work Study) in Tempe, AZ
pros: Interesting day-to-day activities, good office culture, great work environment
cons: Work is often sparse for this position

review_title: Best place I have ever worked!
pros: I was able to grow quickly within the company. They have a unique, family-oriented enviornment that is fast paced and fun. Lots of paid holidays and great benefits!
cons: I cant think of any

job_title: Art Direction Professor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Fast, fun, friendly and smart!
cons: School is located on a busy road.

job_title: Student Services Advisor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Free food from the cafeteria
cons: Lack of formal training, sink or swim mentality, and a toxic work environment

pros: Great place to work while working on your education
cons: The pay is minimum wage

review_title: I'm proud of where I work
pros:
- I've found a great group of friends and enjoy working alongside them each day 
- Working in higher education is fun because you see the innovative and smart ideas these students come up with. It makes me proud to work for a school where I know our students will be successful after graduation. 
- Medical insurance, STD/LTD, life insurance, and AD&D are paid for by UAT 
- 5 free meals per week from the onsite cafe (saves me so much money) 
- Casual environment where people work hard, but they have fun. It isn't a stuffy corporate environment. 
- I learn something new every day. I either learn something new about my role, or I learn something about the tech industry from various trainings that occur on a weekly basis.
cons: - The pay isn't as high as I wish it was, but there are definitely benefits offered that help make up for an average pay grade.

pros: Great benefits, a relaxed and casual environment with a great group of people.  We have a lot of time off, employer paid medical premium with a reimbursement on our deductibles, 5 free meals/week, fun events, summer happiness/movie events, great people.  We have amazing students who are so creative and inventive and make your job fun and worthwhile.
cons: There are some negative people in the building who have been negative for years.  They should have been let go a long time ago for their attitudes or they should have left on their own if they are so upset here.  These people just seem to enjoy making others miserable.  Most have never worked anywhere else and don't get how lucky they are here.

pros:
Great working environment!
   -I've worked in some pretty toxic working environments before (retail sucks).
   -Everyone is very friendly and welcoming.
   -Management makes it a point to know who you are and to present themselves
     as Leaders and not just bosses.
   -I know my Leader has my back.
   -"All-hands" meetings (literally everyone) to promote positive relationships 
     between employees from every department.

Perks/Benefits are pretty awesome!
   -Every holiday off, including UAT specific holidays (Founder's Day)
   -Awesome health benefits
   -They actually have someone come in to explain different 401k/investing
     options
   -Summer Happiness!! :D
   -Free lunch
   -Free education (at the school, either audit or degree)
cons: The job itself isn't that glamorous, and can burn some people out (not nearly as bad as retail). In my opinion, the benefits more than make up for it.

pros: Faculty comraderie and faculty support for each other is fantastic and you can count on them in an emergency.  This is the only reason to work at UAT
cons: There is no longer an area that is just faculty and we can no longer speak aloud to each other.  We must hide in a conference room or someone in one of the other areas will "tell on you" like school children.  There is no respect for the faculty and they are changing our benefits so that we accrue time off the same as the other employees, but we are expected to give 200% w/ no raises and no backing.

pros:
The Dean of Faculty takes care of all her Faculty which makes it easy for the professors to take care of the students.  UAT makes the professor experience great, in turn as professors, we strive to make the student experience great. My hope is for my students to land jobs at places where they will be treated like this.

Other pros are:
The Campus, the cafe, great benefits, hosting events, great classrooms, great open workspaces, the vibe, great Feng Shui, and you get to research and work with new tech like augmented reality and AI.
cons:
The chairs could be better with back support.  This is not really UAT's fault since they didn't build the chairs. 

Having to work some weekends, but since Campus is open 24/7 all year, it is to be expected.

review_title: Passionate Professors & Advisers, but lack of solid management and quality control
pros:
*(For the most part) Great staff and faculty who are passionate about their jobs and interaction with students.
*Quick hiring process and simple orientation
*Good for those who appreciate little to no micromanagement from higher management
cons:
*Lack of communication between departments
*Power divide between management and faculty/staff
*Lack of respect offered to part-time & student workers

pros: great benefits, happy and fun people, relaxed environment, flexible hours, great students, new up to date technology, little red tape, enjoyable atmosphere, lots of vacation and time off, caring company who make the effort to help their employees through personal challenges.
cons: A lot of new grads are hired and they don't know what a job is expected to be.  They complain while they are here, leave and then see what other companies are like and want to come back.

review_title: Great place for students and faculty/staff!
pros:
Great leadership! The leadership has the proper expertise and focuses on the people, which is hard to find in any institution especially higher ed. Usually in higher ed. the leadership is an academic with no management skills. The UAT leadership cares about the people and focuses on staff development and workplace happiness.  The leadership team cares deeply about providing a great education and a unique community for the student body. UAT provides  education and opportunities that are unmatched by any other workplace or school.  The leadership team values the community and works hard to give back or get involved and encourages students and staff to do the same. 

If you like to learn, grow, work hard, but have fun then UAT is a great place to work! If you love technology, innovation, creativity, cutting edge resources, access to industry experts, then UAT is a great place to earn a degree. Not to mention that there or on-campus and online associate, bachelor and master degree options to fit the needs of even the busiest students. 

UAT provides great benefits to students and staff.  There is an advisory board of industry experts who help to ensure that UAT curriculum prepares students to meet and exceed industry expectations. Alumni are welcome to audit courses for free- great way to stay competitive and up to date on technology and business. Alumni are welcome to use Career Services indefinitely. 

Campus living is easy.  Parking is easy (so no overpaying for parking to find no spaces) Small campus so no long (hot) walks or bus rides to classes. No surprisingly high book costs each semester. Great dorm spaces! There are lots of student groups and organizations. UAT has local and national partnerships and contacts so there is plenty of opportunity to network with industry leaders. There are regular Career Fairs and Tech Forums. There is even an exchange program for study abroad options. UAT also hosts students from abroad only adding to the rich UAT culture
As an employee I feel lucky for the chance to learn from the best leadership team and the brightest students.
cons: The con is that I didn't find UAT sooner. UAT would have been my school of choice. The education is unmatched.

review_title: Not the founder's university any longer - great start but deteriorating quickly.
pros:
Extremely dedicated veteran faculty and staff.
Decent benefits, 401k, holidays etc.
Education/professional development policy is comparable to other universities.
Excellent marketing internally and externally.
Up and coming stature in the tech community/Arizona.
cons:
Has become so "sales" oriented in order to obtain students that it borders on unethical.
Opportunity for internal growth practically non-existent.
Few raises - even for Cost of Living Allowance.
Extremely high staff turn-over and dissatisfaction. 
Progressive policies, familial atmosphere, student-centric focus,  is just rhetoric - money is the bottom line in all decisions/policies.

review_title: It's not perfect, but I like it.
pros: I've been here for 11 years, and while mistakes are made in every organization, I do truly feel the leadership has the best interest of the organization and the students in mind. They invest in new technology, and have never balked at a well presented idea for providing technology to meet student needs. The faculty support of student projects has represented some amazing results over the past decade, and they've started ensuring faculty members receive continued training opportunities, to keep their skills and knowledge sets up to date. Students have tremendous flexibility and opportunities in their educational careers. There's also a push to realign all coursework to industry requirements, and communicate appropriate course pathways to students, so they better understand what courses to take, if they want to do a particular type of work. Overall, I really like the school. Over the last 12 months, the University has hired recognized experts in the field of education, to help evolve the curriculum, strengthen teaching methodologies, and provide a liaison for off-campus instructors.
cons: There hasn't been as much communication, over the past 4-5 years, with the student population, regarding which courses will be offered, and when. But as I mentioned before, that's being actively changed, right now. I've seen one of the final, approved, program schedules that's going live this summer. So I'm optimistic.  The work space for faculty and curriculum staff is an open air space, and the lines of communication between the various entities tends to be distracting. But there are some separate collaborative workspaces that can be used, for in-depth discussions. One of the core strengths of the school is also one of its inherent weaknesses, as well. The University hires instructors and professors that are recognized professionals in the industry. Many times, the instructors available to online students are different than those available to resident students. And based on the student's personality, they may find they connect with different instructors than are available.

review_title: The most supportive environment and progressive workplace I have ever experienced.
pros:
Having worked for the university as a full-time employee for over 6 years, I can say that the workplace environment truly supports each of the employees to be their best and grow.  

With competitive pay, generous vacation and holidays as well as 401K matching along with other unheard of benefits I feel well taken care of as an employee.  

Working for a university that has the following VALUES makes me feel part of a great organization and I look forward to being on the team for the long haul:

Integrity - We promote positive social responsibility and global citizenship, and always act with integrity, honesty and ethics above reproach. 

Quality through Continuous Improvement - UAT is a complex system of interrelated parts that shall be continuously improved. We plan, use feedback and seek to understand relationships so that UAT systems will be stopped, simplified, improved or innovated.

Lifelong Learning - UAT is a learning organization. UAT provides the highest level of student learning, seeks learning opportunities throughout the organization and expects individual growth. 

Teamwork - We believe in and foster teamwork. Working in collaborative teams, we support each other, create alignment and build shared understanding that produces superior results. 

Family - UAT values the commitment, support and lifelong growth that come from a learning community built around family principles. Its policies and practices promote healthy interactions within this family context. UAT embraces the benefits of family working at and attending the university.
cons: Unfortunately the university is not as well know as it should be in the education space.  Being a small private university we strive to become more well known for our unique majors and ideal environment for students looking to move technology to the next level.

review_title: Lost focus after founder left the company
pros: All of the reasons I joined this company were eliminated when the founder retired and left the company in the hands of incompetent people who replaced innovation with textbook methodology. Teaching became impossible, students received poor value for their money, and a period of high turnover began. This was supposedly due the recession. If so, then the corrective action failed. The first 4 years were fantastic. My last year at UAT was a nightmare. I was blamed for poor reviews in my classes. How was it my fault after 4 positive years? During that last year, the founder retired, massive changes were made that wrecked the teaching process. Yeah, it was my fault...
cons:
6 weeks of vacation--2 per semester--are rendered useless when faculty have to spend the entire time preparing for the upcoming semester, responsible for building and maintaining their own courses.
 I taught 6-7 different courses per semester. Every term, I was expected to change these courses to meet new methodologies. I was required to choose the textbook, prepare the syllabus, build all of the lessons, exams, activities, gradebook, every semester. It was absolutely exhausting. 
The pace and impossible requirements burned me out. The job ended five years ago so this is not a revenge review. I was relieved when it was over since I'd tried to tough it out. 
Talking with other former teachers, even after many years, we shake our heads at the incompetence that was on display. And, as far as I've heard, positive changes have not been made. 
- No vacation for faculty, it's work or die
- Extremely expensive medical coverage
- Unrealistic expectations by an incompetent provost
- Interference in the teaching process
- Giving teachers busy work that takes them away from instruction
- Horrible in-services every month--basically 8 hours of punishment for being an employee.
- Faculty were treated with contempt rather than as a valuable asset.

pros: You will be entertained by how poorly this place is run.
cons: They will break any rule to keep a student. They are very desperate. The Pay is terrible, especially for a salaried position required to work over 9 hours. They interview you for a job and then offer you another job to keep your salary low. They force advisors to call students’ parents, even if they are 28 years old and tell them not to. They come up with ways to make employees look bad, when it’s their fault. They will fire anyone for anything. There is very high student services department turnover. They have tons of alcohol in their board room and try to drink their problems away, while on the clock. Manager meetings are all about talking bad about employees and who should be fired. No self-blame for poor management practices and lack of direction. They show no care for anyone on the floor. They to make up reasons for firing people. It’s really sick and twisted. I have never seen anything like it. They have no heart. They wanted to fire someone for mental health issues, but this person was doing an amazing job in their role. I was told I need to stop caring about my employees. People are fired for being “too nice”. They don’t have any training for new employees. You are expected to do good within the first 2 months or you are on the way out. They will tell you how much they love you, say you are doing good, give you no objectives or direction and then fire you out of nowhere. They will blame all their problems on you, even if you are new. They use people as scapegoats. They get angry if you spend too much time with a student. They are all about the numbers, will do whatever it takes to keep as many students as possible. They do unethical things to raise a student’s GPA. For example, change a student’s program but don’t apply all classes. They will go way past a deadline to add students to classes. They hand out incomplete's and extensions like candy, just so students can keep going and spending money. They will do anything to keep their own jobs and keep the heat off themselves. They wanted to offer one of my referrals a job but were worried that he would come in and take their job, because his resume looked too good. Everyone in management back-stabs and talks bad about each other. Their systems are old for a school that has "Advancing Technology" in their title. Their processes are outdated. If you want to improve something, they get angry. They beg their employees to give positive reviews across social media sites, to drown out bad reviews. The food in the Café is low quality and terrible. Low and behold, if you disagree with any of the unethical and shady things they do, you are gone!

pros: Got to work with some cool people and earn some money while going to school.
cons:
The bindery position for me was an interesting time. To start I worked there for almost two years while getting my degrees. In that time I felt discriminated against based on the actions carried out. Still till this day never got an explanation as to why she was like this or an apology. 

However, it was hard to feel like it wasn’t because of my race. While I never like to play the race card I really have no other explanation for the things she did. 

Lets begin. Around being at the bindery for a year the bindery lead was graduating and her position would be available for another bindery worker to take. The leads got paid a dollar more and as a college student even that dollar counts (but funny looking back on it now that I’m graduated and salaried). The leadership over the bindery decided that even though I had been there the longest out of anyone there at the time that a new girl would take this position. Mind you I trained her for the position. Now I know just being at a job longer doesn’t qualify you to get promotions but thats what they decided. After five months the new bindery lead rather unfortunately passed away. While this time was sad I didn’t want to be the person that tries to immediately try to take someone that died position so I didn’t want to ask for the position directly.

A new coworker at the time asked me around this time “Do you think you’ll get the position.” I told him no if anything you will because the bindery leadership doesn’t like me. A week later he had the position. I had been there a year and five months and passed over twice for new people that I both trained. 

Now to comments the leadership gave me   As this is not all about getting passed up twice. I once opened the bindery up at 7a. Bindery leadership comes in and I asked if we were out of flash-drives. As we used to sell them to students and faculty. Immediately she rudely tells me. “Ugh I don’t know are we”. I had already looked around and didn’t see if we had stock and she had a special key to check other closets for inventory. None the less she pissed me off but I held my tongue and said nothing. 

On another day I was working on a weekend. A student that had just graduated came into the store and wanted to buy school merch because he was an online student and this was his first time visiting the school. If you’ve ever worked a cashier job before you would know that if someone needs change for bills sometimes its frowned upon to give the person a ton of change in quarters, nickels, etc. Well on this day we had almost no bills and I didn’t know whet to do. So I asked what should I do. Without saying a word she rushes over to the cash register like a maniac and starts slamming quarters, nickels, etc. onto the counter. The guy buying the merch even told her that she didn’t need to have an attitude and throw change. Real nice image of the school his first visit. After he leaves she tries to tell me that she wasn’t mad/upset, but she was just saving face even though she clearly did this in front of another person other than me that would agree about the unnecessary attitude. I didn’t believe her as I had interrupted her from unloading boxes and she hated my guts for whatever reason. 

She once even probed me with questions after telling her that I would not be able to come in the next day after getting my wisdom removed as some sort of way to give me a write up or fire me even though it was well within my right to call out and I gave ample notice. I know this had to be a way of trying to get me in trouble because of all my time working there I was never asked how I was doing (not that I needed them to ask) and yet all of a sudden an interest is taken in having my teeth pulled. Not suspicious at all. 

I took all of these issues to my bosses boss and laid it out for him in a meeting with another coworker.  I detailed how she has never liked me for no apparent reason, passed other staff and I up for brand new employees that we trained. In this meeting he blew smoke up or rears and nothing ever came of the meeting other than him talking with his employee/friend and she now had to tread carefully as now I had made a formal complaint. Luckily he no longer works for the school. 

I then tried to apply for a student ambassador position at the school to get out of my situation. You apply by sending your email to the lady that manages HR for the school at the time. Thats when I get an email from my bosses boss that I had the meeting with that he “Heard a rumor I was thinking of leaving”. Clearly he had been talking with the HR lady because if he could read minds that would be an impressive thing to put on a resume. 

He was also good friends with his employee so I knew telling him would be a risk. But I knew from his email that he would be of no help and that I’d have to go to someone even higher.  

I then went to the provost of the school and told him this whole story along with print outs of the emails I had received. Long story short he also did absolutely nothing and just told me “We need to improve student and faculty relations”. 

All of this happened between 2013-15 and the leadership is still there till this day. When she should have just been let go because I was not the only one she was rude and disrespectful to.

pros: It was an on site job for students for the university, so convenience was huge since I lived at the dorms nearby. Got to meet a lot of other students and staff.
cons: Management was a joke. Passive aggressive emails and favoritism was only the start.  The supervisor at the time used us student employees as her personal anger management device. It was easy to tell if you were going to get chewed out during your shift merely by the mood the super visor was in. Honestly it was so hostile at times I couldn’t do my job, or risk the backlash. Favoritism was also huge, there’s a single position at the bindery that had the role of creating the schedule and was also the person who assigned the work for the day, but instead of this position going to a senior bindery worker, it went to someone with little experience just because the super visor liked them more. It was frustrating when I ended up doing most their job for them just without the pay bump because they didn’t know how to do it. That’s just some personal grief coming out, one of the main problems is that when myself and others went to hr about some of these things, and even higher management(we had face to face meetings to talk about these things) nothing changed, and we never heard about it again. Also most the time we were understaffed so taking time off was impossible and definitely frowned upon. All in all working there under that kind of management ruined a lot of my opinion of the school even as a student, I wouldn’t recommend either to a person.

pros:
There are tons of great people who will support your goals and ambitions.
Flexible environment and understanding managers.
cons:
Feels like administration loses sight of what is best for students.
Administration makes decisions that sometimes don't seem to make sense if the goal is benefiting students and the educational environment.

pros:
- 40 hour work weeks 
- getting the opportunity to connect with some really cool and smart students
- management team is great 
- overall pretty low stress job 
- able to learn about cool new tech 
- good work/life balance
cons:
- not much opportunity for career advancement 
- pay isn’t the highest, but there are benefits that help balance that out

pros: UAT is a very unique excellent environment to work in. The students, staff, and faculty all truly care about every person's success. UAT is a family type environment with excellent benefits.
cons: Some excellent talent has left.

pros: I enjoy teaching young adults in a technology saturated environment.  The management is generally supportive.
cons: Curriculum development falls heavily on instructors.  It is difficult to keep high quality instructors in leading technology fields due to the fact that those individuals can generally make double the income outside of academia.

pros: UAT is my home away from home, my family, and my biggest support system. This is a job that I actually enjoy going to every day. We work hard but have fun while doing so. I honestly couldn't imagine being anywhere else.
cons: Location isn't ideal, but oh well.

review_title: Great opportunity for students while attending the University.
pros: Working as a student tutor was a great opportunity for me. It allowed me to practice my skills while also letting me assist my friends and peers at the same time. It was a win-win.
cons: I can't really think of any downsides for working in the position I did.

review_title: Highly Recommended University to Work For
job_title: Senior PR Associate in Tempe, AZ
pros: As a new employee, I am 100% impressed with the transparency and refreshing honesty at this university. Students are cared for, employees are respected, and opportunities are everywhere.
cons: The only con is getting there from I-10.

pros: Work with students and aided in paying for my college.
cons: Not worth the stress and extra duties that the university expected of us that wasn't in our contracts.

pros: Is that so many other reviews on here over the years have exposed this sham of a school and its poorly run admin staff.
cons: Admin/Management will lie to your face. This place is ethically challenged and is a very poorly accredited school. They bend rules to keep students enrolled. School has an awful graduation rate of 16%.

review_title: Great place to be around technology
pros: Great open door policy for all. Managers listen to your concerns.
cons: Can only take off hours in 4 hour chunks.
